themes: critique of application management and portal usability
panel process inconsistencies and need for equity training
opposition to match requirements and budget restrictions
support for economic mobility for marginalized and emerging artists
role and limitations of fiscal sponsorship
sequencing and structure of funding opportunities
key_phrases: so much respect and see so many AMAZING elements of the funding programs now
No match, no budget restrictions, centering community based orgs, representative leadership, and historical significance to marginalized communities was groundbreaking
The NEA ArtsHERE program was practically modeled after Thrive!
I am not sure the Long Center is very effective at managing the application and money distribution part
The application portal should be more user friendly! User centered design at the forefront
Panel process and training needs quite a bit of refinement
Thrive should all be the same panelists, having completely separate panel groups scoring for the same competitive grant is rife with discrepancies
Panelist training on equity (especially economic equity issues within Austin) and local conditions needs to be CENTRAL
Fiscal Sponsorship is a GREAT resource and should be optional but NOT required
Match requirements are not a good idea
Economic mobility for emerging and low income artists and small/mid-sized orgs needs to be a focus everywhere for ACME
we are hemorrhaging local artists and community-led and focused small arts organizations
barriers_identified: unresponsive and unhelpful application management (Long Center)
confusing and poorly designed application portal
lack of economic mobility for emerging and low income artists and small/mid-sized orgs
solutions_proposed: improve user-centered design of the application portal
refine panel process and ensure consistent panel sizes
require same panelists for Thrive to avoid scoring discrepancies
centralize panelist training on equity and local conditions
make fiscal sponsorship optional, not required
eliminate or allow 100% in-kind match requirements
focus on economic mobility for emerging and low income artists and small/mid-sized orgs
consider sequencing Elevate before Thrive, with Thrive as supplemental funding
implement a two-stage panel process (prelim and finalist) with applicant Q&A
long-term discussion on improving the Thrive cohort model
